questions.question_text: A new office space is being designed. The network switches are up, but no services are running yet. A network engineer plugs in a laptop configured as a DHCP client to a switch. Which of the following IP addresses should be assigned to the laptop?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If no DHCP server is running yet, the laptop will be assigned a self-assigned IP address in the Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA) range. The APIPA range is 169.254.0.1 through 169.254.255.254. Therefore, the correct answer is B. 169.254.1.128.

Selected Answer: B
It should be B. 
The question states that there are no services running, which means there is no DHCP server available for the DHCP client to reach. In this case the device will be assigned an APIPA address. Though I forget the exact range, I remember the first octet because its 169 because 69.
Yes but APIPA then ASSUMES you're already using a Windows system. What if the laptop was running Linux or MacOS?
It depends on how the DHCP server is configured. Without additional information, it is impossible to determine which IP address will be assigned to the laptop.

questions.question_text: An organization requires the ability to send encrypted email messages to a partner from an email server that is hosted on premises. The organization prefers to use the standard default ports when creating firewall rules. Which of the following ports should be open to satisfy the requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C. Port 587 is used for email message submission, typically by clients to an email server. It supports the encrypted transmission of email messages using Transport Layer Security (TLS) or Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). Ports 110 and 143 are used for email retrieval by clients from an email server. Port 636 is used for LDAP over SSL.

Selected Answer: C
A. 110 - POP3
B. 143 - IMAP
C. 587 - Smtp
D. 636 - LDAPS

Selected Answer: C
bro i thought that 25 is for smtp

Selected Answer: C
smtp port 587

choices.A: The client sends all network traffic down the VPN tunnel.
choices.C: The client sends some network traffic down the VPN tunnel and other traffic to the local gateway.
choices.B: The client has two different IP addresses that can be connected to a remote site from two different ISPs to ensure availability.
choices.D: The client connects to multiple remote sites at the same time.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. The client sends some network traffic down the VPN tunnel and other traffic to the local gateway.

In a split-tunnel VPN, only certain network traffic (usually traffic destined for the remote network) is sent over the VPN tunnel, while other traffic is sent directly to the local gateway and out to the internet. This can improve overall network performance for the user, but can also introduce some security risks if the local network is not properly secured.

Selected Answer: C
C. The client sends some network traffic down the VPN tunnel and other traffic to the local gateway.

In a split-tunnel configuration, the VPN client is configured to send only specific traffic through the VPN tunnel while allowing other traffic to access the local network directly. This approach helps optimize bandwidth usage and allows the client to access local resources without routing all traffic through the VPN tunnel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes a split-tunnel client-to-server VPN connection?
Which of the following is the MOST secure connection used to inspect and provide controlled internet access when remote employees are connected to the corporate network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
the MOST secure connection would be a full-tunnel VPN. This is because all traffic from the remote device is sent through the VPN and encrypted, rather than just specific traffic as with a split-tunnel VPN.

comments.content: Yep I agree, however I don't quite understand how it is more secure than a split tunnel from a technical point. We are only interested in securing the relevant stream of data, if the employee is working on a split tunnel and their other data e.g. youtube videos is not being encrypted, how does that impact the security of the company?

discussion.content: so i should read full tunnel as, dailup with split tunnel disabled?

Selected Answer: B
The MOST secure connection used to inspect and provide controlled internet access when remote employees are connected to the corporate network is Full-tunnel VPN. 
In a full-tunnel VPN, all traffic from the remote user’s device is routed through the VPN tunnel to the corporate network. This provides the highest level of security because all traffic is encrypted and inspected by the corporate network’s security devices.

questions.question_text: A network administrator needs to query the NSs for a remote application. Which of the following commands would BEST help the administrator accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
The Linux/Unix dig (short for domain information groper) utility does the exact same thing as nslookup. It’s primarily a command-line utility that allows you to perform a single DNS 
 lookup for a specific entity, but it can also be employed in batch mode for a series of 
 lookups.

Selected Answer: A
dig (Domain information groper) is the command line tool to query DNS nameserver in linux

Selected Answer: A
Dig is the correct answer, only on that makes sense

- The "dig" (Domain Information Groper) command is used for querying the Domain Name System (DNS) to obtain domain name or IP address mapping.
- The "netstat" command displays network connections, routing tables, and network interface statistics.
-The "arp" (Address Resolution Protocol) command is used to view and manage the ARP cache, which contains mapping information between IP addresses and their corresponding physical (MAC) addresses on a network.
- The "tracert" (or traceroute) command is used to determine the path that packets take from the source device to the destination device on an IP network

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct is answer as : The BEST command that can help a network administrator query the NSs (name servers) for a remote application is the "dig" command.
'Querying NSs for Remote Application - comptia - Exam-Answer'
Definitely dig=> used on Linux.

Selected Answer: A
its dig

Selected Answer: A
Agree with A being the correct answer here
